results.content: I'm grasping things without difficulty.  This course is as well written as his other course: JavaScript: The Weird Parts. I'm really enjoying. Only one caveat, and it isn't enough to make me change my grade, but the continuity of the course was broken by the section where he's showing us code in Microsoft Visual Studio. I wish he had (at that point) shown us how to connect our Angular App to a database so that we could do it with him rather than just watch it. I wrote down his code, but I'm sure I won't remember it. I'm assuming we're hooking up a database later, so I'm not changing my grade. I really like this course.

results.content:
Over the past 7 months, I have been focusing on transitioning into Web Development from other areas of technology and have been coming back and forth into AngularJS; I have taken 5 professionally prepared AngularJS courses  (not counting those using NodeJS) and have used numerous resources as well.

Without reiterating exactly what Anthony teaches, the most Important Excellent Attribute of his course is this.  Tony Explains Concepts that I otherwise was 'just' becoming familiar with and 'including in my code'.  This is extremely beneficial ! For instance,  Dependency Injection is a simple concept but Anthony's manner of Applying and Explaining the 'Resources' that are made available because we inject a  Module, Clarifies this important functionality.   I have never before use $log !  Extremely useful.
  
We build our own Services and again 'this' - no pun intended - really cleared a bunch of things up.  

At times, Tony drills back down into javascript and html to somewhat parallel what we are actually doing with AngularJS.  We 'Inspect Element' all of the time to Visualize what our code renders and he shows us that at times our code shows up when we Inspect Element and sometimes it does Not but Explains why this happens ! 

There is so much more I can add about the technology Tony teachers.  He also reminds us - at some point - that most Web Developers are self-taught.  Well - that is reassuring although when we learn from someone like Tony, we are taking the initiative to Learn but of course, a Course like this is instrumental.
I wish that I had started with this course months ago.
Thanks Tony.  You are an excellent teacher.

results.content:
Anthony does a great job introducing AngularJS.  It is a beginning level course, but he walks students through the necessary information to build a working single page application, running from a local server.  

Basic understanding of Javascript is recommended, but he will stop and explain the necessary JS to complete the course.  He is great at communicating what code is executing, and what is being handled by Angular, as opposed to simple providing instructions to follow.

My only criticism is how Anthony reviews some information.  It can be difficult to track a thread of information as he switches files  and scrolls through the code.
results.content_html:
Anthony does a great job introducing AngularJS. It is a beginning level course, but he walks students through the necessary information to build a working single page application, running from a local server.

Basic understanding of Javascript is recommended, but he will stop and explain the necessary JS to complete the course. He is great at communicating what code is executing, and what is being handled by Angular, as opposed to simple providing instructions to follow.

My only criticism is how Anthony reviews some information. It can be difficult to track a thread of information as he switches files and scrolls through the code.

results.content:
I am an engineer with 26 years of programming experience in many different technologies.  Back in the day I was developing generation 1 CGI web software but moved to front-end software development.  This made AngularJS seem like we were going to have a very steep learning curve.  Along with so much garbage on YouTube and complex articles with people expecting you to know everything it made it seem impossible for me to get my staff trained on AngularJS quickly.  We're WPF programmers and the previous web projects have been a little rough.

You explained the concepts in a clear and concise way with plenty of time for absorption.  We all came out understanding how this tech works and why certain things are done in certain ways.  I can say this course saved us hundreds of hours of self-learning that would have given us inconsistent final results and a poor first application.  Value on this is tremendous.

Everyone said they loved it.  I loved it.  We are all now ready to write our first commercial application using Angular JS

Thank you from the programmers at smartborder.com

results.content:
The course provided by Anthony is very clearly structured and presented fluently providing exactly the right hints and comments in the right situations. I am a JavaScript engineer working mainly with a other frameworks as part of my job, but wanted to gain detailed insights into internal concepts used in the Angular way like Dependency Injection, View Model Binding and Transclusion. I had advanced JavaScript knowledge before, but the course did exactly met my expectations. I'm really happy that I found Anthony's course. Please continue like this. I am looking forward to watching other courses made by you.
Thank you very much!
Kind regards, Domi

results.content:
The course is excellent as well as the tutor. I hadn't realised this is such an old course and not relevant anymore. Even examples won't be compatible with the latest versions of Angular 1, as the instructor is using Angular 1.3. Even though I learned a lot, I felt like I wasted my time and should gone directly for an Angular 2 course. 

If you're looking to buy it probably don't do it - go and learn Angular 2 instead as most of this here won't be relevant.

I wish Anthony updated this course to be compatible with Angular 1.5 - I'm a big fan of his style.

results.content: Great course but I would have given this a higher rating if the author/teacher kept it updated (since Angular has changed since this class was launched) and responded to questions more often. I see a lot of questions go unanswered. It seem as though the author/teacher has abandoned this course. If so, then this class should be removed from Udemy. The small updates like the one he provided in the weather forecast SPA section does not give enough information. I had to spend more time reading other peoples answers to questions to try and solve it - which is fine. But if people like myself are paying for the course, we shouldn't be getting outdated material. For instance, this course was built around AngularJS 1.3 but there was a huge update from 1.3 to 1.6. The author/teacher should provide the updated material in the course in order to successfully complete it. Again, I still think this course is great because the explanation is done well but the explanation is nearly useless if it is outdated.

results.content:
This course should become a case study in what teaching is all about. 

I was annoyed at some presumption and clumsiness apparent in some Angular decisions. In fact, especially after hearing about 2.0,  I was almost willing to leave it alone. I've seen lots of horrible APIs disappear in the past, so I was ready to wait. 

Anthony "gave me" back Angular and with it the renewed prospect of a more short-term specialization as front-end developer. Because of his incredible generosity, knowledge and method, I made peace with some of the less generous parts of the technology (aka directives), and finally understood the motivations behind some decisions, how the framework engine behind-the-scenes was driving the API semantics, how it was leveraging the browser's basic java script engine. After this, I honestly plan to follow any course Tony comes up with!

results.content:
I bought this course for only ten euros, and it has definitely been worth it.
It would have been great with some more exercises, and more real world scenarios - especially in terms of catching errors (thinking of $resource/$http services, promises, etc.).
That said, if you are new to Angularjs this course is a great starting point!
 I played the videos at speed 1.5 - if you are a native English speaker, or good at English, I would recommend the speedup, as it's quite easy to follow a long.

results.content:
I'm basically watching all of the high rated Angular tutorial's I can find between Udemy and Pluralsight. Disclaimer: this is my third so far, so most of this was review to me.

Pros:
So, this course is actually pretty good. The content is paced slowly. Anthony takes his time explaining some of Angular's magic, rather than leaving you to wonder. This is definitely tailored to Angular beginners (which I like). He never leaves me behind and always proactively answers the questions I was thinking (like, what if I want to minify my javascript and my parameters get renamed). He has a video on that.

Cons:
I do have some criticisms. First, Anthony is really dry. He's boring and cheesy (Big word alert with 1995 powerpoint animation). I wish he were more engaging and fun like Asim Hussain's tutorial is. Next, I wish he covered more popular modules. He should update the course to cover Angular 1.5's component's and external router modules (Which, I only know about because of Asim's Udemy tutorial and Scott Allen's Pluralsight tutorial). I think he should also include popular external modules that company's would expect angular devs to know, to help us prepare for those jobs. Say... a section called "10 most used Angular modules", and spend like 10-15 minutes on each. I would like another section called "Angular on the Job", and have it include some best practices and expectations of an Angular developer at a job.

Summary:
I do recommend this as your very very first intro to Angular. I do not recommend this if you already know some basics. This video is also a bit dated, and comes before Angular 1.5 components. The speaker is boring, but he is very easy to understand and speaks clearly.

results.content:
I consider Anthony Alicea one of the best (if not the best) instructor for the numerous courses I took on Udemy. I took two courses by this author: a couse on Java Script and this one.

I wanted to give 5 stars to this course, since it truly makes you understand AngularJS, however I decided to take off half a point since the course is outdated (if I am not wrong, the course was prepared at the end of 2014 and it references AngularJS 1.3).

I wish Anthony added some new chapters for later versions of AngularJS (for example AngularJS components).

I would also recommend to take "AngularJS Custom Directives with Dan Wahlin" after this one.

results.content: I had some prior experience with angular before this course, so I knew how to do certain things, but this course helped me understand how it works behind the scenes and why are things done the way they are done. Angular seems easy at the beginning but as soon as you make the first step beyond beginning, it gets really complex. When that happened, I became anxious about each new step being a landmine. This course took that anxiety away and made playing around with angular a much more enjoyable experience as I now know a lot more about what I'm actually doing. However, if I was completely new to angular, I think that the parts I enjoyed the most - explanation of how things work - would be boring. So to get the most out of the course, I would suggest taking the course advertised on angularjs.org home page first and take this one immediately afterwords.

results.content:
This and Anthony's other JS-Course are some of the best learning-resources on Angular and JS on the web. 
The big difference is the repeated explanation of basics and fundamentals, which most other courses skip, or speed through.
Especially for web-devs who have more of a design- than CS-background this is a must-have.

A great addition to this would be a bonus-course or lesson about persisting data with a simple backend or localStorage, so you can get the feel of a real-world app much faster.

I hope Anthony will make more courses like this one (Node or Backbone/React maybe?). 

Thanks!

results.content:
Dear Tony,

Thanks for a highly professional course, in terms of structure, content, accuracy, polish, explanation, and pacing. Your voice is clear and you only say what is necessary to explain. I needed a quick introduction to AngularJS, and having spent time trying to work through the standard tutorial example, and an example-based book I was more confused than I should have been. I managed the Weather Report mostly by myself, and have learnt enough to get started on my first application, which is a conversion from an existing PHP server-side application. The custom directives isolated scoping is complex, and perhaps could benefit from further explanation and justification. Otherwise, one of the best lectures I have had the pleasure of attending.

I look forward to further of your courses.

Thanks

Roger

The custom directives isolated scoping is complex, and perhaps could benefit from further explanation and justification. Otherwise, one of the best lectures I have had the pleasure of attending.

I look forward to further of your courses.

results.content:
This is one of the most awesome courses I have ever attended.

Even though I know a bunch about Javascript (which is a prerequisite), I knew absolutely nothing about AngularJS; yet right after this course, I developed my first quite-complex application without struggling, 3 times faster and with 3 times fewer code I used to do with jQuery. Now I just love Angular and I'm wondering why people even use jQuery :)

The instructor starts from scratch, meticulously breaks everything down, speaks slowly and takes all the time he needs for you to understand.
The most awesome moments were when a question popped in my head, and at that moment Anthony was like "There, I know what you're gonna ask, here's the answer, here's how it works". Wow!
I have warmly recommended this course to everyone around me wishing to learn Angular.

Congrats Anthony!

results.content:
Most tutorials are based on "training" - repeating tasks, memorizing procedures to complete tasks. (Also circus animals can be trained to perform some tasks) This course is "teaching" people - understanding how things work and then completing tasks.
I am taking this course in 2017, that's funny but for some reason Angular is still popular. This is not a place to review Angular, but I have to reflect upon bonus material in this course referring to "future" Angular 2 as it was seen in 2014.
I am a JavaScript enthusiast. That refers to ECMAScript 3,5.
This language is superior to all of its predecessors namely C languages, including Java.
The superiority comes from the fact that the creator Brendan Eich could take what is the best from the older languages and create something brilliant.
Brilliant ideas are usually conceived by extraordinary individuals and then the committees of bunches of ordinary mediocre people try to destroy it.
The popularity of JavaScript attracts developers from other old languages. (The C-people)
Those developers are completely lost in JavaScript and for them the language takes a step backwards and we have ECMAScript 6!
Funny fact, JavaScript is so resilient that can emulate old languages so the C-developers can write code like C-minus-minus, C-blunt  and then transpile it back to the original JavaScript!

results.content: I really appreciate the thoughtfulness that went into the examples as well as the author's dialog. The author does an extremely solid job with content structure, content delivery, and reinforcing the lessons for each topic. He will start with a section of Angularjs, demonstrate how to implement the feature, explain why it is useful, explain if there's another way, demonstrate that, and then near the end of the lecture, recap on what he is trying to help the audience understand. This is a very effective approach to teaching, in my opinion. I have this foundation that loops the structure of "Learn it. Again. Again. Again. You can do better. Again. Again. Again. Okay, good. Repeat loop." I think that the core concepts are explained well, and that anyone new to Angularjs would be impressed with the course content, structure, and delivery. The audience will definitely be able to walk away and use the lessons learned to start building something in Angularjs. That is my theory. I haven't built anything yet, but the author (Tony) has instilled this confidence in me to do so. Thank you, Tony. I really do appreciate this course, as well as your JS: Understand the Weird Parts, and the Nodejs course. I'll have to go through them a few more times before everything sinks in, but I'm motivated for sure. To everyone interested in the course, I would recommend to give it a try. See if the material, the pace, and the structure is one that you can benefit and grow from. Cheers.

results.content: I have just finished Tony's course. As a former teacher myself, I am highly critical (despite myself) of other educators. I can confidently say that Tony is an exceptionally talented educator, who realises that redundancy in a course is important for concepts to gel in the learner's mind, and that actual practice is fundamental to understanding and memorisation. Thank you Tony, I feel that you have given me a very solid base upon which to build further knowledge and hopefully the next chunk of my career.

results.content:
I really enjoyed this course, and wish i'd found it about 12 months ago before I started working on a major Angular.js project, it would have saved me a lot of time !

As it stands I already knew a lot of the material via trial-and-error while developing on a project - I would class this as a beginner course - though that is definitely no bad thing. Even as an intermediate Angular developer I found it very helpful to consolidate what I already knew, as well as understanding some of the internals such as dependency injection (which I normally just take for granted).

I would love a few intermediate / advanced level tutorials to really get into the guts of the framework and explain some of the advanced features in depth (and under the hood) as well as some of the non-core modules such as angular-ui and probably also a separate course on protractor as I've found it harder to master than Angular itself !

Thanks again Tony for a great course!

results.content: Anthony is very, very good and well-versed in his JavaScript knowledge and this is about the best, most well explained, course i've found anywhere on Angular, and i've been through several tutorials; at Treehouse, Code School/Pluralsite, the angularjs.org site tutorial, etc. none of them come close to what Anthony does here in very simple language, explaining the harder terms and concepts well — i loved his "big word alerts" — and made me feel i really had a grasp of how to do things in Angular.js. my only criticism is i would have liked him to update the course and spend more time on upcoming Angular 2.0 features, beyond ES6 and TypeScript/AtScript mentions and links to go to those sites. other than that, most all the coding examples were great, and i really feel like i understand controllers, services, routes, and directives in Angular. thank you, Anthony! great job!

results.content:
This course was a refreshing change from your average "Hello World" courses.
The "understanding" part in most courses is almost always missing. However,  the instructor gave an extremely thorough overview of each new topic BEFORE diving in and using it (including the elusive WHY its important part) . 

His teaching style immediately put me at ease. Even as we jumped into the "deeper things" of Angular I was able to follow along and build out the projects without frustration.

It's a lot to take in, but it moves right along without loosing you. Still, I will probably watch it again and refer back to it as needed. It was that good. :)

results.content:
This is the first course that I have completed on Udemy, and I had an enriching experience participating it.
Anthony Alicea is a great instructor and focused a lot on understanding the concepts that drive Angular JS in becoming such an efficient tool for Single Page Applications. I especially liked, how the instructor arranged the content, and touched base on 'Asides' as their usage was introduced into the Angular environment. 
I started this course having a very primitive idea of Angular, and have completed the course with the confidence of getting started with basic Single Page Apps. I have also learnt a lot of Javascript in the process. 
Would recommend the course to anyone looking to learn and understand Angular.
I gave this a 4.5 rating, since there is a scope to update the part of the 'Let's build an App' module, to focus on how to implement the call to 'OpenWeatherMap' website with their new 'App ID Key' requirement.

results.content:
I learned a lot from this course and, overall, it is well taught.  The instructor is clear, organized, and anticipates students' questions, etc.  

My only criticisms would be that the course needs to be more hands-on and to provide more projects for students to build their confidence and understanding with.  I feel as though this course is quite introductory, considering the mammoth nature of Angular JS and its marketing should reflect, with more specificity, exactly what you (as the student) will be able to do (and not be able to do) by the time you have matriculated through the course!  Would recommend, however, to truly use Angular JS in your own projects, it is clear that more training will be needed.   Having an understanding of the under-girding framework is awesome, but most people take courses like this because they want to build enough skill to be able to actual put their knowledge to productive use within the context of real-world projects.  Although this course wouldn't get someone to that place, necessarily, it is an important first step and should be seen as such.

results.content:
Glad I took this course. Angular is still fairly new and as such there aren't many good courses on it yet. I had done a couple others previously and took this one to really solidify the MV* framework idea and see how it should all fit together. I felt like I finally started to grasp it after taking this course, so I'm walking away satisfied.

results.content: I wanted to give credit where it is due, the teacher is very well aware of the ins and outs of angular js and all things that it entails. My favorite part about the course is that he keeps it simple and explains how things work in angular js via pure javascript examples, after all AJS is just javascript. I've tried multiple courses, all where I felt like the instructors themselves were just throwing big words around and not really explaining how something works. If you're like me and hate to just be told what to do, this is the course for you! I don't like being told "okay this is how you do this in AJS" I like to know WHY and what is the core reason behind how something works. I'm so happy I bought this course, worth every penny and I want to tell Anthony to PLEASE keep on making more course videos, you're doing an awesome job!

results.content:
Having tried to learn angular using a reference book, and then online examples and then finding myself tasked with completing a half-built angular app at work, I realised everything i'd be cramming up to that point was irrelevant. There is no point trying to understand the syntax, when you have no idea of whats going on behind the scenes - and thats what the author of this course realised. In this course, you are talked through all the various mechanics in angular, and all the complicated, unfamiliar terms you will encounter are broken down and explained simply. The course then moves onto using angular for real world scenarios, and the examples are all situations front end developers will have found themselves in time after time, so this helps you follow what is going on and you start to take in what you're being told - and remember it too, which is the most important part of learning something.

I can't recommend this course enough!

results.content: I like that this course teaches the "WHY" behind many of the techniques used in AngularJS. I have taken several introductory courses in AngularJS and most will, for example, show you how to use the link function. This course teaches you the long way of doing what the link function does and then shows you why the link function is best to use as a shorthand to doing all of that code. If you want to know more about how AngularJS works under the hood then you must take this course!

results.content:
Hello,

I started this course with an open mind and high enthusiasm. Couldn't finish it because :

- it's not updated with the new stuff at all ...
- the exercise (this referees to the point above) does not work -ish...
- has no "production" feel and touch
- no modularization (everything is in the app.js...)
- several things like promises, filters etc are not discussed at all
- some very small examples...wanted and expected something more (at least at the end for the weather app)

I guess it's an okay course but nothing more, as I haven't learned that much from it (some concepts here and there and nothing trully solid). Appreciate the effort tho :)

- several things like promises, filters etc are not discussed at all
- some very small examples...wanted and expected something more (at least at the end for the weather app)

I guess it's an okay course but nothing more, as I haven't learned that much from it (some concepts here and there and nothing trully solid). Appreciate the effort tho :)

results.content:
Definite 5 stars, as the importance was more on the concepts' "WHY" rather than the "HOW". I completed the course in a day and night as i enjoyed listening to the tutor. For me, the icing on the top was the compile and link directives explanation and the object map for the function binding directive scope object "&", both which i really struggled to understand before. However, i would have loved to see a bit more topics being covered ( point taken that this is a beginner level introduction rather than deep dive) 
> form validation, nesting with ng-forms, and a bit more peek into enhancements post angular 1.3 ( the ng-messages/track by index etc )
> Though $resource has been touched upon, its more on the surface level.
> Promises which is indeed a confusing topic for many.
> A sample demo of integrating a jquery plugin into the angular, which is a common scenario in projects.
>Adding controller inside directive and the usage of the 4th parameter inside the link function along with scope, elem, attrs
>Though you have mentioned lightly on services Vs factory vs providers, could have been a bit more comprehensive as i am still confused about is as to , if the end result is a singleton, is it more of just an artistic choice ? Or is there a differentiation based on scenarios?
>The HTML5 mode and the URL differences that come along with it
>$parse Vs $interpolate Vs $compile
>Configuring the ajax requests ( which needs to be done in a  normal scenario ) transformRequest, transformResponse
in the $http/$resource , access object concepts
>Intersceptors ( another confusing topic indeed )
>Practical difference between using .success() and .then() using $q library.
>Animations ( nothing has been mentioned even on surface level)

>Testing ( which is a huge topic on itself, so hope to see a comprehensive tutorial for Test driven development with karma + jasmine + protractor )

This was just a small wish list that i had and by no means a criticism. I enjoyed every bit of this course!

Thank you.

results.content:
Instructor is clear, easy to understand, starts at the basics, and picks up topics quickly through the course.

EDIT ** HALFWAY THROUGH **

This course is wonderful; if you are using or thinking about using Angular 1.x, this course will have material relevant to you. I think it's targeted more towards beginners (which is why code versioning isn't implemented for the source code available). The instructor does indeed go beyond coding up a framework and tells you why pros and pros and cons are cons, and covers a lot of relevant bases. The effort the instructor put into the course is telling, visible, and very impressive. If there are other relevant, highly rated and taken courses by this instructor, chances are they will be of a similar quality.

** EDIT: FINISHED COURSE **

Absolutely stellar course. I think I bought the "Understanding Node.js" and "JavaScript: Understanding the Weird Parts" courses already; they and this course are very much worth the money. You will learn a ton.

results.content:
I took this course knowing nothing about AngularJS and now thanks to Anthony, I am able to understand and write a little bit of it. Main and most serious problem with the course is that the Anthony didn't update since september-october 2014! What this means is that many new things could have been introduced to AngularJS but we wont know them. Also the examples given especially reading data from external resources are really not well done. In some scenarios there will be a missing API code that everyone needs but the lecturer didn't provide, and then there will be building a whole weather forecast to read data from open API (but even that doesn't work anymore with the instructions he gives since the website changes its policy)! 

if at least alternative routes or quick fixes like annotations are used to highlight the changes, then that would be great. But I guess the material never changed since being created and I worry this course shortly is out of date.

results.content: I was fortunate to pick this up on the New Years sale pricing and I can't say how satisfied I am with the course. The thorough explanations and content provided in this course serve as a great reference material even after course completion. I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in to diving in to Angular. Not only is the documentation explained, incredibly well; it's also explained incredibly thoroughly. I've sifted through some of the Angular documentation on the API and it can get confusing to read through, really fast. This is where Tony shines as he isolates each Angular functionality to "how it was done" and what the developers did to improve the previous methods as well as how they went about doing it. This material in the course alone, gives the user clarity and assists in further deep diving in to specifics. A big shout out to you Tony, you're an incredibly gifted teacher and know how to reach out to a large audience of people. Your NodeJS course is definitely next on my list. Cheers.

results.content: I really enjoyed this course.  Anthony does such a great job explaining the concepts behind AngularJS he almost makes it too easy.  I suggest taking notes as you go along.  He explains the functionality of AnguarJS as you go along and wraps it all up with fully functional project.  I found by the end, I forgot a lot of what he went over in the early parts of the course and needed to do some back tracking.  A great suggestion would be to create a little ebook we could reference as we go.  I would of made it a bit easier to remember what custom services were towards the end of the course.  Super easy to follow along and never felt like I was lost (until he got into directive scope that is :).  I will buy any course Anthony teaches because he's so easy to learn from.  Thanks Anthony.

results.content:
Anthony Alicea is a great teacher.  A lot of courses try to get you up and running with a framework as quick as possible.  While this approach has merits, it can lead to confusion later down the road because you're memorizing syntax without understanding fundamental concepts.  Anthony's AngularJS course is a slow burn.  He explains WHY AngularJS does something a particular way, so the HOW comes naturally.  

As an example: where some courses would say "here's a weird bracket syntax thing that Angular does with dependency injection, just remember it", Anthony explains how AngularJS chooses this syntax to handle injector errors caused by minification.  As a result, I'll never forget this syntax.

Explaining the framework in this way isn't just about "making it easier to remember".  Frameworks are built on top of core language principles, but they are constantly making decisions about how to do things.  Calling these decisions out is a great approach to learning not just AngularJS, but any framework. 

The course is definitely for beginners.  But it builds a foundation and gives me the tools I need to confidently explore the framework further on my own.  After taking this course, going through a "Build an <insert app here> clone in AngularJS" walkthrough is a much richer experience!

Thanks for the great course, Anthony!  I look forward to more.  If you're open to suggestions, I would love an Angular2 course.  Another idea is a course that explains 'fundamental web development' concepts, like a deep dive exploration of the full stack.  With your style, a course like that would be a monster!

He explains WHY AngularJS does something a particular way, so the HOW comes naturally.

As an example: where some courses would say "here's a weird bracket syntax thing that Angular does with dependency injection, just remember it", Anthony explains how AngularJS chooses this syntax to handle injector errors caused by minification. As a result, I'll never forget this syntax.

Explaining the framework in this way isn't just about "making it easier to remember". Frameworks are built on top of core language principles, but they are constantly making decisions about how to do things. Calling these decisions out is a great approach to learning not just AngularJS, but any framework.

The course is definitely for beginners. But it builds a foundation and gives me the tools I need to confidently explore the framework further on my own. After taking this course, going through a "Build an clone in AngularJS" walkthrough is a much richer experience!

Thanks for the great course, Anthony! I look forward to more. If you're open to suggestions, I would love an Angular2 course. Another idea is a course that explains 'fundamental web development' concepts, like a deep dive exploration of the full stack. With your style, a course like that would be a monster!

results.content:
I bought this course right after I finished Tony's other excellent course: JavaScript Understanding the Weird Parts!
Tony's JavaScript course was phenomenal because it broadened my understanding (and my liking) of the JavaScript language. We delved deeper into the working of JavaScript and understood why things behaved the way they did. Tony also provided tips on how to enhance your JavaScript experience and avoid errors that are difficult to debug.

So I started this course expecting the same kind of treatment. I had already developed with AngularJS before (not extensively, but was familiar with the basic concepts) so I figured I was ready to delve deeper into what's going on 'under the hood' (like Tony says!). While the course did provide some insight into how Angular works on some occasions, It didn't match my expectations (remember I set my expectation based on the previous experience that I had with Tony's other course: Understanding JavaScript). I was ready to learn more about how things worked behind the curtains.

That is not to say you shouldn't buy this course! Not at all. This course is very helpful for those trying to get into Angular (though it might not be the best introductory course out there). But if you already know the angular concepts (controllers, directives, services, ...) however slightly, this course might not deepen your understanding by much.

results.content:
I was very impressed with this instructors content.  He did a great job teaching Angular.JS from the ground up.  As opposed to most courses i've seen online (and the reason i don't take many) he didn't just give you sandbox examples... He taught the logic from the bottom to the top.  This is essential in learning any language or framework and after viewing his preview on youtube i immediately purchased the course, went through all of the videos, and solved the issue I'd been running into within minutes once I finished the course.   I also must say that the instructor is very engagjing and easy to listen to.  I love the ability to play the videos at 1.5x or whatever speed you prefer, but the instructor is not as boring as most programming instructors seem to be; quite the opposite in fact.

Thanks for taking the time to make this course and if you're out there considering whether to take it or not, just a word of advice, if you're looking for a ton of functional examples, this might not be the course you want... but, if you want to be able to write your own examples, and understand why those work, this is the course for you.  

5 stars all the way around.  Thanks Mr Anthony Alicea for making the engaging content and thanks to Udemy for the great interface to present it on!  Great Instructor and Great platform.  I'll definitely use this service again!

I also must say that the instructor is very engagjing and easy to listen to. Thanks for taking the time to make this course and if you're out there considering whether to take it or not, just a word of advice, if you're looking for a ton of functional examples, this might not be the course you want... but, if you want to be able to write your own examples, and understand why those work, this is the course for you.

5 stars all the way around. Thanks Mr Anthony Alicea for making the engaging content and thanks to Udemy for the great interface to present it on! Great Instructor and Great platform. I'll definitely use this service again!

results.content:
A clean intro to AngularJS. I was underwhelmed by how deep it goes, and the quality of code that was written (i.e. the interface for the weather directive), and his understanding of good coding practices.

If I had paid over 100 Euros I would rate this worse, because this is at most an introduction. It does not delve into advanced angularjs topics.

I bought this because:
- I wanted to improve the quality of my angular JS code
- better understand the nitty gritty of how AngularJS works under the hood -> investigating complex scenarios

It did not really achieve that due to being basic, and mediocre coding.

results.content: I have been looking for videos all over YouTube to get started with AngularJS. It has been several years since I programmed and it really wasn't in JS back then. Most of the videos out there seem to assume the audience is comprised of computer scientists or veteran programmers. This courseware spends at least some time on covering the underlying basics of HTML and JS that allow AngularJS to work. Most of the courses I have found seem to practice the teach how to pass the exam and not teach to understand the material model. They often explain how/what to type in, but spend zero time explaining how it works. This courseware prepares for the test (real life) by instilling an understanding of how it works. I guess one gets what they pay for. Money well-spent :)

results.content:
This course was well structured making it easy to follow, and thanks to that getting back to certain topics is also very easy.

All items were well explained and I also liked these "aside" lectures and "big word alerts" because they emphasized that this is something not strictly related to the topic in hand but are important to know to not get confused with the main topic.

Now, the Internet is full of examples and even free courses where they just show how to do things. This course had an approach which I liked more: to understand things. Anyone can copy and mimic stuff and see that hey, it works, but I like to understand why things work and how things work. This course emphasized that and it was actually why I chose this and not a free AngularJS course that was offered as an alternative by my employer.

All in all, a well structured, well explained course with an approach I like. An excellent course. I enjoyed.

Wow best tutorial i've seen. Wish there were courses like this for all topics in computer science. The instructor explains everything very calmly without rushing on anything. He shows everything he does very thoroughly with examples so that you really follow whats going on. 

Besides the instructor of the course, the content is also great. Most of the tutorials on the internet only teach you how to do things in angular but not how it works behind the scenes. This course is awesome as it does both. It explains how angular works in detail and also how to do things in practice. It gives a lot of background information about javascript itsself to make things easier to understand. Its a very well prepared and structured course.

I saw the first 50 minutes of the course for free on youtube and at the end of the video when I found out I had to pay for the rest I wasn't even pissed :P. Nice job!

results.content:
Its a good course for the beginners who are looking to learn angular.
As usual Tony is awesome!  I liked the digest loop section.
But,
I feel it should have cover few more topics like
1) Should have a section about $inject service
2) Comparison of various custom services like factory,service,provider
3) And most importantly course is missing unit testing using any popular libraries like jasmine, karma

Please either add any bonus lectures for unit testing or else provide separate course on angular unit testing.

2) Comparison of various custom services like factory,service,provider
3) And most importantly course is missing unit testing using any popular libraries like jasmine, karma

results.content: While this a good explanation of Angular, bear in mind that it is outdated (2014). A few examples will only work with Angular 1.3 (current version is 1.6) and there are a few problems with the instructor's JavaScript, ie neglecting automatic semi-colon insertion, stating everything in JavaScript is a function, neglecting to mention that certain examples will not work without a (local) server, etc. Taken along with other solid resources (Angular JS official tutorial and docs, Eloquent JavaScript, etc) it can be useful. This course absolutely does need to be updated.

results.content:
This is a long review. If you want a recommendation on *the* course to take for Angular, and if you're trying to find the course that will finally 'crack open' your understanding of Angular, then you just found it.

So, here is my typical pattern for learning a new framework like Angular. Pick a course, learn, and try to create my own app. Simple right? Well, not quite. You see a lot of courses try to 'front load' the framework. Download the framework, install, and start to build an app, learning some of the cool things that the framework can do along the way. It's instant gratification. It feels like I'm learning loads.

Problem with me has always been, that after the course is finished I find I can't really put what I've learned to use. Why? Because I have really learned by rote. I have a loose conceptual idea of what the framework does, but, I don't have the understanding of what's going on behind the scenes, so I feel that I can't create something publishable. I am not confident enough that I am using the framework the right way and I'm afraid that what I'm building might not be built using proper methods or patterns.

With Angular, there are simple ways to do things and there are deployment ways to do things. I remember getting caught up regularly with things like this... You learn your framework (or so you think) and realise that the way you were creating your modules was wrong, it worked, but when you compressed your code for publication for instance, it broke. You had to change your code around - you're in a hurry and you're not *quite* sure why you had to change what your changed but, hey it's working now, but are you confident with your changes and can you recreate this the next time and understand what you're doing?

You go to look for help on Stack and find that the answers are couched in terms that you may not understand (Angular has a lot of terminology), so you've got to go looking for definitions of those terms. On and on you go down the rabbit hole, trying to learn the framework essentially back to front!

This course changed all of that for me. Every single concept of Angular is explained from the ground up. You don't start with creating an app - you start with understanding exactly what Angular is, and how it works, *and* it's fascinating and highly informative. Watchers, the digest loop, services, Angular context, directives, singletons in services, creating your own services, modules and on and on... everything you need to know about Angular is there, but you only start building any sort of real app about half way through the course. And this is the beauty of this course. When you start building, you know and understand everything you are doing, and you have the language - the vocabulary you need, to being to think like an Angular developer.

Not only will your understanding of Angular be of a much higher level, but now when you go to search for that help for your Angular project online as you continue to learn, you will be able to ask the right questions, and just as importantly, you will be able to understand the terminology in the answers and you'll be able to sort out the good information from the bad.

This is a superb course. It doesn't provide the 'instant gratification' of some other courses, it manages to provide many more and lasting satisfactions along the road as it opens your eyes to this brilliant framework.

For the first time, I can walk away from an Angular course with the confidence to build the app I want to build, safe in the knowledge that I can now use the documentation on the Angular site and ask for and understand the help I need on the forums to continue with the framework.

This course should be called 'required viewing' by the AngularJS team. Many thanks to Anthony Alicea for making this.

results.content:
This course aims to get you started with your AngularJS career. It is great for almost anybody.

Beginner - Check. You'll come out of this course grasping the basics of AngularJS and confident enough to start on your own applications.

Advanced - Check. You'll come out of this course having a greater appreciation of how AngularJS works behind the scenes.

Anthony knows his stuff. You can tell not only on how confident his voice and tone sounds, but by how he simplifies all the explanations. He makes complex look easy.

I've finished taking his Javascript course, and just wrapping up this AngularJS course. I am now excited to begin his NodeJS course. Yes, I bought all three.

By the way, I forgot to mention, I consider myself a backend developer. I am one of those unfortunate ones who took Javascript for granted early in their careers, thinking that it's nothing more than a fancy UI tool. Now that it has come into its own, I realize it's high time to give it the respect it deserves by sitting down and understanding its power.

Anthony's courses do not disappoint. I can now say that I know this beast. I haven't tamed it yet, but I am now equipped to start on the journey of strengthening my frontend skills.

If you are one of those who feel the same way, what are you waiting for? Take this course now. :)

Most excellent! Really, really good, just what I was looking for and the instructor is perhaps the most knowledgeable I've seen todate on udemy (and there's been a lot of really good ones)!

I have a project that I hope to complete by the end of this month. I started out trying to do it with only jQuery and Sockets.io thru NodeJS but found that I was soon developing a three or four separate frameworks and worse, having to go back over these frameworks exponentially to get things done. I got as far as trying to do a simple user login/register when I happened to stumble upon AngularJS. Between Udemy and yourself, you've made my life so much easier!

Also, as a direct result of your course I picked up your two other courses on JS!

Thank you!

Perry

results.content:
Tony actually explains the workings of the layer that is called Angular. Just as in his NodeJS Udemy course, he explains why the given tools are created and how they actually work, instead of simply explaining how to use the tools.

Of course, you can drive a car when someone explains you how you should do it, but when you know what's going on under the hood, you have a much better understanding why it's responding as it is and you have a much deeper understanding of how it works AND how you can use that to your benefit.

results.content:
The course is well thought out, the concepts and execution of AngularJS are clearly explained, and the bonus lectures provide valuable real world insight into using AngularJS in production.

All other books and tutorials I have read on AngularJS have focused on the mechanics of what code to write, and offer no real insight into why you would choose AngularJS or even the logic behind the code. Anthony should be congratulated for creating a course that explains what AngularJS is, how it is structured and what the significance of that structure is to you as a developer.

Overall a highly recommended course.

results.content:
This is a fantastic course.  I came to Javascript through various front-end frameworks and this not only helped me understand the "black box" that Angular uses to operate, but deepened my understanding of Javascript, as well.  Mr. Alicea goes through all of the core concepts and breaks down a lot of the jargon thrown around into very easy to understand ideas.

The author also shows us errors and missteps and explains how he goes about discovering the problem.  He shows which resources he's using for his information and explains where to go for more.

This course made Angular far more approachable to me and I look forward to more courses from him.  Highly recommended for junior developers (like myself) who are interested in learning more about how front-end frameworks operate.

results.content:
The course is made up of byte size. The title is what as it says , "Learn and Understand". Do not rush, follow the convention used in this course, especially the module and controller structure. I have seen many angular tutorials, with different conventions. Pick up one that suit you and stick to it. The things I like most in this course are: Anthony will talk slowly, clearly and into the points, make you understand what the Angular jargon's are, for example: Directives, Interpolation, dependency injection etc.
How it benefited me: I now understand AngularJs basics, which is very important to me. How the angularJs bootstraps, linking multiple controllers to View(s), URL Routing, templates, extracting data from  JSON object etc.

Thank you.

results.content:
Haven't written anything in AngularJS before and this definitely was perfectly structured from basically nothing to going into a bit more detail. 

Only reason why this isn't 5/5 is because I would've loved some more explanations to what different parts can be applied to. Realize it's impossible to foresee every use but some basic examples. E.g., for me as a PHP programmer, I can't help but feel that I'd rather loop through stuff in PHP and then return a result rather than having AngularJS do the looping, etc etc...

But very good for getting a grip of the syntax and the basic!

results.content:
**update**
it would've been good to know that i need a localhost or hosted server in order to run SPAs on Chrome. took me a couple days to troubleshoot that but now I have wamp on my computer and am using plunker as a good site to just test my js code on. 

i wish there were more assignments, that way i could have a little guided use of the code. it's cool because i can figure out little projects to do on my own but it would be really helpful if there were maybe little projects at the end of a concept that would help to really cement the learning and prove how useful the tools of angularjs are to us as programmers (not that it needs a lot of proving--mostly just that personal experience is often the best teacher). 

**back to the beginning**
so far it's really good! the instructor, mr. alicea, takes you through all the ins and outs of the basic infrastructure of angular so that you can understand the power and potential as well as nurture a strong semantic understanding of what's meant by angular terminology. really great! i feel energized and eager to learn more and get started with the SPA (single page application) project!

Phenomenal beginner course for learning Angular! Tony is thorough and clear.

My only (minor) criticism is that it seemed inconsistently paced. He took forever to explain some simple concepts, leaving me hopeful about the more challenging lessons. But then he hurried through the complicated parts which I thought deserved as much (if not more) attention as the basics.

All-round an excellent course! Highly recommended if you are a beginner to Angular.

results.content:
Good course covers all the basics well.  The course is written using an older version of bootstrap and AngularJS but I followed the lastest and had no major issues.

I saw some people mentioned in their reviews that the URL for the final app doesn't work, this is true but the author includes a slide with updated details. If you follow the instructions it all works.

There are some elements I think should have been covered for a full understanding like custom filters, controllers in custom directives, and factories but generally, all the basics are covered well. 

Buy it :)

I am a computer engineer, so not really a beginner.
But I am quite new to front-end developing.

I liked how the teacher domains the concepts and introduce them in an easy way.

I had a rough time calling the REST service in the exercise. I made my excercise with the latest AngularJS version, and the way the REST service is called has changed since the course was made.

See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44255292/how-to-access-external-resource-json-data-via-resource-in-angularjs for more information.

Thanks.

results.content:
Before starting this course,I had 'learnt' or rather seen or used by copy/pasting and modifying, all the angular concepts taught in this course. I would get stuck often while coding, because I did not fully understand why I was doing what i was doing.

After taking this course, I am extremely confident that I 'understand' how angular works and its not 'magic’. 

Pros
- The course is very well structured
- The sample app covers all the concepts taught previously and is well placed at the end.
- Explanation of “big words” and how they work are superb.
- Directives were very well explained.


Cons
- Only for people who have some idea about various angular concepts, you will sorely miss a playback speed control on Udemy if you are watching on non iOS device. (of course for someone new to concepts and non-native speakers of english i think its perfectly paced)

Thanks Anthony Alicea, I am taking your Javascript course too..

results.content: This course helped me get up and running quickly with AngularJS.  I was writing useful AngularJS code not even half way through the course.  AngularJS has now become a primary language that I code with every day and I've become a more valuable player at work.  My background is more Java, and not so much Javascript, but Anthony is a fantastic teacher whose explanations and demonstrations made this accessible to me.

results.content: The strategies he uses for explaining the things is very understandable. The usage of examples to get into the topic is very good. I highly recommend him for this course.
results.content_html: The strategies he uses for explaining the things is very understandable. The usage of examples to get into the topic is very good. I highly recommend him for this course.

results.content: Great course.  Now at the bonus lectures.  A very good course for an intermediate developer.  Just a note about the section on directives, specifically about templates.  You should probably stress that the template should be contained or enclosed under one tag.  While I was doing the weather App and setting up a directive for the report view I kept getting errors because my template was not contained in a single tag.  While I was debugging this problem i accidentally clicked on a link in the console which brought me to an angular page that explained this to me finally.  Another problem I had was the weather app required the openweather API which sadly got recently shutdown by google.  I figured a way to use the resource module to call the google locate api to give me coordinates from a given text query for a city and chained it to another call to this api https://developer.forecast.io/ which takes coordinates and finds a weather feed for it.  It might be a good exercise to do in future versions of this course since it demonstrates the use of multiple API calls.  In closing thanks for giving this course.  I will be taking your node.js course very shortly.
results.content_html: Great course. Now at the bonus lectures. A very good course for an intermediate developer. Just a note about the section on directives, specifically about templates. You should probably stress that the template should be contained or enclosed under one tag. While I was doing the weather App and setting up a directive for the report view I kept getting errors because my template was not contained in a single tag. While I was debugging this problem i accidentally clicked on a link in the console which brought me to an angular page that explained this to me finally. Another problem I had was the weather app required the openweather API which sadly got recently shutdown by google. I figured a way to use the resource module to call the google locate api to give me coordinates from a given text query for a city and chained it to another call to this api https://developer.forecast.io/ which takes coordinates and finds a weather feed for it. It might be a good exercise to do in future versions of this course since it demonstrates the use of multiple API calls. In closing thanks for giving this course. I will be taking your node.js course very shortly.

results.content:
This is the perfect course to take for a beginner to AngularJS. 
It introduces and explains the key concepts and practices of AngularJS, without assuming, like so many courses do, a background in computer science. 
That explanation, in turn, helps aid in understanding modern Angular (6) as well, by providing a reference for more presumptuous courses (such as those at Ultimate Angular).
The final project, built from the ground up, provides an overview and example of how everything learned before comes together in a real-world Single Page Application. As a former Meteorologist, I can vouch that it is a pretty good weather app, too!
Once again, thank you for your unique clarity and straightforwardness on the topic, Anthony!
results.content_html:

results.content:
After going through Anthony's Javascript course, I would rate this only 2 1/2 for the following reasons :- 
1. I assume that this course of Angular JS was released well before the Javascript course. So this course was not so detailed as the Javascript course.
I can't blame the author as this was the first course in Udemy (If I am not wrong) but would praise him a lot for improving a lot from this course to make other courses (Javascript) a terrific one.

2. The second reason is though this course was very nice but only focus seemed on SPA ( Single Page Application). Is Angular JS not used for any other applications which are not SPA? Please clarify.

3. I think the course is also very small and many more topics could have been covered or existing topic explained more in detail.
 
In conclusion, my expectations were very high from this course after watching the Javascript course but it was very disappointing . But for beginners, I would still say, first follow this course to get the fundamentals and then move to other courses which is sad though. 
If I have any doubts in Javascript, I don't need to go anywhere else. Just visit Anthony's course again and again.

I trust Anthony and I am pretty sure that if he brings up Angular 2 course, it would be like Javascript one.

Again good course.

results.content:
'Don't imitate, understand'. This is a key approach to teaching which makes this and the rest of Anthony's courses the best I've seen on Udemy.
There are many online courses out there that ask you to blindly follow along and complete tasks or projects, without explaining the concepts, methods or the reasoning behind them. It ultimately leaves you with little confidence and no in-depth knowledge to work on other projects. This is certainly not that kind of course!
Alicea's course on AngularJS has a great outline; with each little chunk beautifully delivering on a concept or thought process, and it does not overwhelm but rather it engages and excites. And the 'Big Word Alert' demystifies a lot of terms that could be off putting for so many people.
Most importantly, this course helps you to LEARN and UNDERSTAND the framework, so that you can truly have it a skill which you can further develop and apply to other projects. 
I can't recommend this course enough for both newbies and seasoned developers looking for a deeper understanding of AngularJS. It is definitely worth it.
Thank you, Mr. Alicea.

Very clear and very well explained course. The author organized it well, got well prepared, spoke clearly and slow enough (occasionally maybe a bit too slow for me) and emphasized enough the parts that deserved it.
I liked Tony's way of teaching very much - it's not just listing the features of the language/syntax and showing examples , but actually going into why is something like it is, why is it possible not good and/or how that influences you.
Listening to his courses is like being back on a University, but I wish all of my teachers were this good, instead just some of them.  Sometimes, not often, a course was a bit too slow for my liking, but it depends on your experience. 
I actually took his next course, on JS, although it was probably a bit too basic  - I thought I may learn something I missed so far and clear out some vague stuff and it was worthwile.

results.content: Great course. There is one small little 'hitch' in it that prevents me from giving it 5 stars. Sometimes, as you progress through the lessons, the instructor starts out with a 'clean' page (the previous lessons are cleared from the code). This is easy enough to duplicate but there was one disastrous issue when I hit lesson 27. At some point in an earlier lesson, we had written angular code to expect a json response from an XMLHttpRequest. Brackets (the software used to code the course) got 'stuck' on that expected response. Even after wiping the code and writing the code for lesson 27, brackets (thus chrome) kept throwing an error. The error normally means a page (or entity) we attempted to retrieve was not available. But in this case, it meant my html page I was trying to retrieve was not a properly formatted JSON object. It took me over an hour to debug this issue and to fix it, I was forced to reboot my machine and this 'cleared' brackets from thinking all responses to angular requests needed to be JSON objects.
results.content_html: Great course. There is one small little 'hitch' in it that prevents me from giving it 5 stars. Sometimes, as you progress through the lessons, the instructor starts out with a 'clean' page (the previous lessons are cleared from the code). This is easy enough to duplicate but there was one disastrous issue when I hit lesson 27. At some point in an earlier lesson, we had written angular code to expect a json response from an XMLHttpRequest. Brackets (the software used to code the course) got 'stuck' on that expected response. Even after wiping the code and writing the code for lesson 27, brackets (thus chrome) kept throwing an error. The error normally means a page (or entity) we attempted to retrieve was not available. But in this case, it meant my html page I was trying to retrieve was not a properly formatted JSON object. It took me over an hour to debug this issue and to fix it, I was forced to reboot my machine and this 'cleared' brackets from thinking all responses to angular requests needed to be JSON objects.

results.content:
I love how Tony explains things. He is really clear keeps you in a high level of energy and attention, making you feel enthusiastic about the contents of the course.

The Aside lessons about other key concepts, like Javascript, are awesome. It is also a good selling point for his other courses... ;)

I don't give it 5 stars because, after all, the course is pretty basic, sometimes a bit too slow.

I have spent a couple of days trying to build my own angular app and I am finding out that I am missing important Angular concepts such as factories, event management, or... "the angular way" to deal with the DOM.

Because at the end of the day,  there are some classical and common things you have to face in real world and those ones are not explained in the course and I found myself using stackoverflow too often because of a lack of Angular concepts understanding.

This is the first time I pay for a course like this and I am glad I took it regardless of some points could be improved.

results.content:
I first took the "Javascript: Understanding the Weird Parts" course because I was kind used to "understand by doing" style. The "understand by doing" has it's advantage: You have a steep learning curve, however, after a certain level, you start to spend a lot of time trying to UNDERSTAND what's going wrong. 

Tony's approach is different. You better UNDERSTAND from the beginning, and it will save you time in the future. I just couldn't agree more! I was so excited about his teaching style that I decided to take "Learn and Understand AngularJS" just because he was the teacher, and not because I had a deep interest in the subject.

I just couldn't be happier! Both are 5 star courses and Tony is very attentive and objective in his answers! Can't wait for his next course!

results.content:
This course is amazing. I took another course in AngularJS that really glazed over a lot of stuff left as "magic". I hate magic. Thanks to Anthony I'm gaining a much better understanding of how the bigger picture works. As a side benefit, he's clearing up some other confusions I've encountered in web development and computer science in general. Awesome course, awesome instructor.

I'm coming from an ASP.NET, MVC background and if you are too I would strongly recommend supplementing this with "AngularJS for ASP.NET MVC Developers" which is a nice short course that will get you on the right foot. I wish I had taken that one first since I've done all the lessons in Visual Studio and really not done it optimally until about half way through when I encountered related problems.

results.content: I had been working with AngularJS for about 6 months when I encountered this course.  This course helped me overcome "the dip".  That time when Angular had worn off its novelty and I began to struggle with some of the intermediate and advanced concepts like transclusion and the difference between link and compile for example.  The one thing I wish had been included with the course was testing with karma, jasmine, and protractor.  But other than that minor complaint, this is the best for learning the concepts.
results.content_html: I had been working with AngularJS for about 6 months when I encountered this course. This course helped me overcome "the dip". That time when Angular had worn off its novelty and I began to struggle with some of the intermediate and advanced concepts like transclusion and the difference between link and compile for example. The one thing I wish had been included with the course was testing with karma, jasmine, and protractor. But other than that minor complaint, this is the best for learning the concepts.

results.content:
Anthony does a great job of going through the WHY AJS does what it does and give just enough detail to give understanding without overwhelming. 

I recently took an MEAN stack boot camp and found myself struggling after the class was over to write my own web apps. I have spent hours and hours bashing my head against Sublime Text trying to get code to work. Hours reading AJS documentation and code examples but I found most of the information too deep for me. They were explaining details I had not grasped using vocabulary I did not have.  I realized that the boot camp taught me how to write a directive but never taught me WHAT the directive was really doing.   I really feel that this video has solved that problem. 

Thank you for making these great videos.  I am off to Learn and Understand Node.JS.

results.content:
Aside from the fact that the material in this course is largely outdated (and I'm not even talking about Angular2; just updates to Angular 1.x), there are serious issues with the way the course is constructed. 

For starters, I would expect that anyone taking this course has at least a base level understanding of vanilla Javascript, in which case entire lectures within the course will be downright painful to sit through, even at 2x playback. Even the method of introducing these odd digressions – a flashing graphic titled "BIG WORD ALERT" – comes off as condescending, much less the content of therein. 

Then, there's the frustration of sitting sitting through hours of lecture, watching the instructor click back and forth between text editor and browser, without any clear objective for the audience other than to just sit there and watch. What about a project git repo to at least play along? Nope. If you want to keep up, you have to download a ZIP folder for each and every lesson.

My advice: if you understand even the most basic tenets of javascript, don't count "being talked down to" among your hobbies, and/or value learning at something exceeding a snail's pace, steer clear of this course.

results.content: Highly recommended! Anthony goes through all aspects of AngularJS with so much depth and understanding that I'm very close to feeling confident at least to an intermediate level with AngularJS (maybe even close to ADVANCED with some review and a little more practice). I've taken other AngularJS courses/tutorials on other sites, but the DEPTH Anthony goes into each topic adds SO MUCH MORE VALUE than tutorials that simply define a feature and immediately show you how to use it. For instance, he gives a bit of history on how routes evolved from vanilla JS' hashchange event and location property which helped me better understand SPA routing, in general.

results.content:
Just finished the AngularJS class. So much better than anything else I could find. Totally agree with needing to UNDERSTAND the code. 

Perhaps these ideas are more advanced for an introductory course but consider adding a lecture on creating custom filters and/or best practices for designing large-scale Angular JS applications. Perhaps you might also discuss under what circumstances it would make sense to use multiple controllers at the same level in a view (not nested).

Keep up the great work!

results.content:
Excellent course. I'm not a native english speaker (I'm brazilian), but Tony explains and speaks so well, I rarely used the subtitles .
Pros: Very complete. The "aside" and "big word alert" videos are great to explain something that is related to the course but maybe you don't know. The way he talks and programs is easy to follow, learn and understand.
Cons: I missed contents about form validation (pristine, dirty, etc) and promises (the reason I didn't give a 5 stars rating).
Conclusion: I'm satisfied and I recommend this course.

results.content: I have gone through a ton of tutorials including those on egghead.io, tuts+, random youtube videos, an online programming course, and of course man video tutorials from udemy. The instruction that Mr. Alicea provides is slow enough that you can really follow what is going on. I can't tell you how frustrating it is when you have to stop and pause a video every 30 seconds because they are moving way to fast and not explaining the purpose behind every action they do. The 'Asides' sidebar he uses in the video are perfect for getting people up to speed on relevant information BEFORE going into the topic. Great course, great instructor!

results.content:
Unlike a lot of other video courses and books I've tried to learn Angular from, this course does a really great job of introducing the core concepts and practical knowledge I needed to feel confident to build my own small app. It's a great place to start off from.

Angular is clearly a huge framework and this course certainly doesn't turn you into an expect but I found it a great jumping off point, and I'm hopeful the instructor offers a more advanced course in the future.

That all said I paid £20 for it which felt good value.

results.content:
Best course on Angular 1 that I have ever taken.  I have taken other Udemy courses, other Pluralsight courses, CodeSchool courses, and some books, and none explains Angular as well as this course does.

This course takes the time to explain HOW Angular does its magic, so that you can UNDERSTAND what is going on.

The examples are small, but cover the material.

By taking the extra time to explain the underlying plumbing, Angular gets demystified, and you can see what is going on under the covers.

The course starts with the basics and goes into topics other authors stay away from, such as making custom directives, using $watch, $apply and scary things like transclusions.  Some of these scary things have been simplified from impossible to just hard, but they can be learned and then used by you.

I am even going over the course a second time to ensure that I understand all that was provided.

This is the best course on Angular 1 ever.
By value, it should be a $50 course, but the author wanted to make it affordable to more students.
results.content_html:
Best course on Angular 1 that I have ever taken. I have taken other Udemy courses, other Pluralsight courses, CodeSchool courses, and some books, and none explains Angular as well as this course does.

This course takes the time to explain HOW Angular does its magic, so that you can UNDERSTAND what is going on.

The examples are small, but cover the material.

By taking the extra time to explain the underlying plumbing, Angular gets demystified, and you can see what is going on under the covers.

The course starts with the basics and goes into topics other authors stay away from, such as making custom directives, using $watch, $apply and scary things like transclusions. Some of these scary things have been simplified from impossible to just hard, but they can be learned and then used by you.

I am even going over the course a second time to ensure that I understand all that was provided.

This is the best course on Angular 1 ever.
By value, it should be a $50 course, but the author wanted to make it affordable to more students.

results.content:
Unfortunatley this course is kind of deprecated as Angular is already out and AngularJS is in LTS mode. A lot of example do no longer work for current AngularJS (1.7.5 as I am writing this comment) the way it is described in the course. Examples:

- $http.get no longer provides "success" and "error" methods. As it returns a promise, "then" and "catch" can be used
[https://www.udemy.com/learn-angularjs/learn/v4/questions/5353684]
- the routing with "#/name" is does not seem to work, instead "#!name" does work but this is not mentioned in the course
[https://www.udemy.com/learn-angularjs/learn/v4/questions/4618918]
- for weather API example at the end you have to change the resource.get to not use callback and JSONP. => $resource("http://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather/?APPID=YOURAPPID")
[https://www.udemy.com/learn-angularjs/learn/v4/questions/2390654]

Nonetheless I think this course is still good and it could make sense to book it if you want to know about AngularJS (angularjs.org). If you look for a more current solution, an Angular (angular.io) course might be the better.

I booked this course after taking Tony's NodeJS course for getting a better understanding of client side web programming. I am not much of a JS programmer and did web development with HTML, CSS and PHP in the past. For my purpose this course was just fine as I think it gave me a lot of insight on how client side scripting can be done.

Regarding the way Tony made up this course I think this is just great. Each section comes with code examples so you always have a good starting point for doing your own coding or you can just check how the code should/may look like. Also each sections seems to perfectly build upon the previous one so you slowly get into the topic with every lessen. I also enjoyed the weather forecast app at the end of the course where one could build its own app by just combining the elements learned in the lessons before.

So I think the course in general is really good. However, as some examples do no longer work, I cannot rate it better. As AngularJS is in LTS mode now, maybe Tony can put the course up to date as there are most probably no API changes in AngularJS in the future.

results.content: What a great course. I came into this course with some minor knowledge in JS and front-end development. This course, as well as the instructor, make it easy to understand the ins and outs of AngularJS. This is also a great course to take if you're wanting to get into hybrid mobile development using Ionic.

results.content:
I have struggled to learn AngularJS because many of the tutorials made some terrible assumptions: you were an HTML/CSS/JS expert, you could learn by copying code, etc. None of these assumptions were true in my case.

I learn best when someone takes the time to explain HOW it works and WHY it works - instead of just showing "Here, it works". 

I literally bought almost *every course* this instructor had - that is how fantastic this course is - and I am confident you will love both him and this course.

I have to say this: I have taught various CS subjects and programming languages for the better part of the past two decades; still, there was much that I learned from this course, not just about AngularJS, but also about how to teach a complex and detailed subject. The man is simply amazing!

The subject has been presented very systematically, in bite-sized chunks, and the complexity kind of creeps up on you, and before you realize it, you have a pretty good grip on this fairly complex framework. Anthony's explanations drill it into your head.

If you are serious about web development, I would highly recommend that you take this course.
