results.content: Great intro to Angular. The Javascript asides that talk about the "inner" workings of Angular are also great, aided to the understanding of Angular's "magic."  Do you have another Angular course that deals with Angular CRUD?  So far, the SPA discussed in this intro course doesn't need to interact with a backend database. How can one submit a form to the server to process the model? (so the model can be used as a query parameter, or delete or update a specific record). I'm not asking how to make the server-side programs, but I'm asking how Angular will talk to my server-side programs that's expecting a <form> data.  Thanks.

results.content:
The best introduction I have seen to AngularJS.  I had been trying to learn it for about a year now, off and on through other courses, but always got dissuaded by how much work it always felt like vs. what the reward was.  I already knew how to make web applications, but not the "Angular Way".  From this course I learned a great deal about how the Angular Way may seem more complicated than it actually is.  I have converted one of my web apps to Angular using the information from this course, and it greatly increased the maintainability and readability of the code (while also trimming it down considerably).

I still  wish it went over more about debugging issues that I encountered while applying the basics to my own web app using Angular, specifically with services & directives, but I still feel it's a great deal better than the in-person courses I have taken for AngularJS (that's right, multiple courses and it still didn't "stick" until I took Mr. Alicea's).
Thank you!
results.content_html:
The best introduction I have seen to AngularJS. I had been trying to learn it for about a year now, off and on through other courses, but always got dissuaded by how much work it always felt like vs. what the reward was. I have converted one of my web apps to Angular using the information from this course, and it greatly increased the maintainability and readability of the code (while also trimming it down considerably).

I still wish it went over more about debugging issues that I encountered while applying the basics to my own web app using Angular, specifically with services & directives, but I still feel it's a great deal better than the in-person courses I have taken for AngularJS (that's right, multiple courses and it still didn't "stick" until I took Mr. Alicea's).
Thank you!

results.content:
After searching the web for a solid introduction to learning AngularJS (book, website, etc...), I was surprised to find that not a lot of highly rated content exists (yet?).  That is, until I came across this course.  It was very highly rated, and by more than a few people... so, I signed up and am very glad I did.

The instructor does a great job presenting AngularJS and the main concepts in a clear and informative way.  I am also very pleased with the amount of material I was able to learn, and really enjoyed the video presentation and hands on approach of this course (as compared to reading a book and trying to stay awake).  He has a new fan in me, and so does Udemy... although I'm afraid the benchmark may be set very high now :).

The ONLY improvement that I can even think to mention would be related to the audio quality of the lectures (very hard to understand without headphones on).  The instructor does mention that this is actually as designed, however, as the audio is geared towards supporting students on mobile/tablet devices.  I was using my high-end desktop setup, and needed headphones to clearly hear... no big deal.  I highly recommend!

results.content:
Of the many courses I have completed here at Udemy, this is one of the most well done. The instructor is very thorough and makes most of the concepts very easy to understand. 

The example project at the end uses nearly all of the concepts presented through the course and is a good way to wrap up. 

I have two small suggestions: 1) Make all of the course materials downloadable as one large zip file. It gets a bit tiresome to do it for every lecture. 2) More example projects! I think if the author created an additional course of just examples, that would be well worth the time and effort.

Overall very well done and presented wonderfully.

results.content: 5 star perfection, with just a few minor gripes that have nothing to do with his amazing teaching effectiveness... he uses a very annoying & unpopular IDE (Adobe???) that displays files twice in the left vertical nav tree bar... when he clicks the file below, the selection switches to its mirrored location up above. Sublime, Atom, NetBeans, or Eclipse would have been a much better choice since they are what most people are familiar with. And gripe number #2, has a lot to do with gripe #1 above, in that other IDEs allow you to split pane and cascade your workspace so that multiple files can be viewed at once. The instructor does so much toggling between files quite frequently, that at times, I found myself having to rewind 10 seconds several times, just to follow his file toggling. And since superior Angular design principles would have you as the coder compartmentalizing your code into many segmented files, a more UI-friendly IDE with split pane views would have helped tremendously. BUT BESIDE MY HIGH-MAINTENANCE preferences, I thought this was one of THEE best instructors on Udemy (I own Udemy video content from at least 40 different instructors, so this claim actually means something). Why do I think that? Because understanding programming concepts are better than just mimicking concepts via copy & paste, and this instructor explains EVERYTHING in a way that gives you tons of insight and a-ha moments. Learning to understand, saves the coder so much time and headache whenever roadblocks arise and it's time to troubleshoot.

results.content: This is a well-done, clear, and appropriately-paced introduction to AngularJS. One annoying problem. The instructor correctly says that AngularJS apps are single-page apps. But an AngularJS app has multiple HTML files, that contain fragments of HTML, not whole pages. These are properly called "views". But the instructor chronically calls them "pages" and even names the folder in which he stores them "pages" (instead of "views" as it should be). This is really confusing to beginners, since the app actually has just a single page.

This is really confusing to beginners, since the app actually has just a single page.

results.content:
Excellent course - I'm always feeling like I don't really understand a language because I don't understand the core concepts behind what i'm writing, even if I can write it just fine. Anthony explains core concepts and phrases like "dependency injection" (which every other tutorial just assumes that you understand,  by the way) in an easy to understand way, and does it right before you need it when you're learning the code, so you have that understanding fresh in your mind when you learn a new concept. 

It's not a perfect class - i would occasionally still be confused with how to do things, and I feel like it would be helpful if there were projects that were included - like if one of the lectures described what I should try to create and then leave it to me to do it - and then go over how you do it later so I can compare my work to yours. The only project we got was the one at the end.

I also feel like I would have liked to see more from angular, as this course seems like it barely scratches the surface, and I'll definitely have to go elsewhere to improve my knowledge. 

Finally, Tony explains new concepts but doesn't really provide use cases for them, so for things like custom directives - especially in the final project -  i'm doing a lot of work to create a custom directive which doesn't really save any space, it just makes things a lot more complicated but puts a few lines of code in a different file. 

Regardless of that, I can practice on my own and I feel very good about learning this, so i'm happy. Thanks Tony!

results.content:
Es war gut, dass gewisse Fremdbegriffe verständlich erklärt wurden und man jeden einzelnen Aspekt separat behandelt hat und nicht mehrere Dinge gleichzeitig versucht hat, zu erklären.
Jedoch war es manchmal zu kurz erklärt, sodass man unter Umständen den Faden verloren hat, wenn man sich bestimmte Stellen nicht nochmal angeschaut hat.
Auch z.B. das Quiz mit exakt einer Frage, welche direkt davor beantwortet wurde, war nicht sehr hilfreich.
Möglicherweise wäre es ganz hilfreich gewesen, wenn man ein Quiz an bestimmten Stellen im Kurs eingebunden hätte und Dinge abgefragt hätte, die schon etwas zurück lagen, damit man eher sieht, was man sich noch einmal anschauen sollte.
Das Beispiel-Projekt am Ende war noch einmal eine gute Zusammenfassung dessen, was man im Kurs gelernt hat.

results.content:
As someone whose programming experience is limited to C++, HTML & CSS (who has only stuck his big toe in JavaScript). This course does everything that it sets out to do. 

Tony Makes AngularJS easy to understand by not just outlining "How to use AngularJS", but he sets up the context of each lesson by clarifying the founding principals of each lesson's subject.

Anyone who understands the logic of Object Oriented Programming &  Web Design will be able to boldly set off into the world of AngularJS.

results.content: If you want to learn AngularJS this is the course to take! The instructor actually explains how everything works, down to the tiny details. Usually when you see a tutorial on AngularJS (or anything else really) the person who made the tutorial at one point does something and says: don't worry about how that works it just does, you don't need to know how it works. That's usually a mistake because something about how that works is extremely important to understand a complex concept. The instructor for this course never does that, he always goes under the hood so to speak and shows you how something works which later helps you out in understanding other complex concepts he introduces (dependency injection, linking, transcluding, etc.). All in all I now feel extremely confident writing an AngularJS app and was extremely happy to see that the instructor also has a NodeJS course which is something I've always wanted to learn more about but never found good material. Based on this course I will definitely get the NodeJS course and am extremely excited that the course also includes the use of AngularJS alongside NodeJS which is fantastic :D

results.content:
I thought the course was great, overall, for the amount of time needed.  A few topics I felt deserved more coverage included:

1) dealing with errors. This is a pretty  unforgiving environment. Many of the errors don't get flagged in your own code by the interpreter. They get flagged deep somewhere in the angular code base. I don't know if there are any good guidelines for how to interpret those errors, but it can be hard to trace those back to the problems in your own code.

2) I wished some simplified approaches had been covered for some features of the framework. For example, for directives, the course mentions that you don't HAVE TO isolate the scope, but it is a good practice. Still, I found the "poking of holes" to be cumbersome, and, when I write my own directives, I am in control of variable naming in both the controllers and the directives, so I feel I can avoid conflicts. Therefore, I wanted to try not isolating the scope. I ran into issues making that work when I departed from the course. Namely, I had problems getting iterator variables to pass through to the templateUrl. Since not isolating scope is actually the simpler approach, I would have liked to see that demonstrated end to end in the course.

3) I feel that the course could use a few more high-level views of the architecture of angularJS.  This is a system with a number of moving parts. The course dives into the various parts without spending a lot of time relating them to each other, except by example. But the architectural view of  how they all fit together is not strongly presented. The student is left to assemble that system level view on their own. So, for instance, before diving into building directives, Anthony does explain a purpose that they serve. However, it would make the whole ensuing conversation much  more enlightening to have first explained how directives are situated in the architecture, when they get invoked, and how they relate to other components. That's just an example.

4) minor nit: I ran into a lot of situations where my browser was caching old versions of my files. Refresh is not enough to get rid of them sometimes. I had to clear browser history on many occasions. Unless you know to do this, you can be befuddled by why your changes are not having any impact on the app's behavior. It would be good to explain this to students.

Having said that, I really like:

1) the objective of understanding how the framework operates behind the scenes, so it does not seem like magic and you understand what the framework needs from you.

2) the pace of the course is very reasonable. Perhaps pause just a second or two before switching screens while in the middle of writing code. Switching too fast makes the user constantly have to rewind to look at the code as a guide while entering the code in his/her own editor.

3) the demystification of "big words". It's a very good point that many of these concepts are not nearly as fancy as the vocabulary would indicate!

results.content: Tony does a great job of making AngularJS clear by starting from first principles and building from there. He wants to make sure you actually understand why you are doing what you are doing, not just mechanically copying  what he is doing. It takes longer to get to the fun stuff, but once there, you know why each line is added and why it's important.  Tony makes Angular clear -- which is not to say he makes it simple, since it isn't -- but he unveils the whys behind the power of Angular so that you can actually start using it yourself! Great course and highly recommended.
results.content_html: Tony does a great job of making AngularJS clear by starting from first principles and building from there. He wants to make sure you actually understand why you are doing what you are doing, not just mechanically copying what he is doing. It takes longer to get to the fun stuff, but once there, you know why each line is added and why it's important. Tony makes Angular clear -- which is not to say he makes it simple, since it isn't -- but he unveils the whys behind the power of Angular so that you can actually start using it yourself! Great course and highly recommended.

results.content: Whatever course Anthony teaches in the future, I’m 100% going to take it. This guy’s courses are so good, are so well done, that I wish Udemy had an auto course sign up for the authors of your choice. I’ve taken lots of courses on Udemy and I’ve given several 5 stars to some of the courses, but this is the first time that I was compelled to write a review. I’ve been working with JavaScript for several years now, and in the last year began “Learning” Angularjs. The problem was there was a lot I didn’t really understand, which made the code more difficult to debug when things went wrong and ultimately led to a frustrating experience. The way Anthony first lays down a foundation for you to build your understanding of the topics is brilliant.  I’ve already taken “JavaScript: Understanding the Weird Parts” which was also exceptional, I will be going back to write a review. If you can’t tell from this review, I can’t wait to take his course on “Learn and Understand NodeJS”, which I anticipate that I will give the same type of review. At the end of the day, I did “Learn” and I do now “Understand” the fundamentals of “AngularJs”, and will continue to use the course as a refresher. Anthony, please produce more excellent courses on web development and I will follow your lead.

results.content: Great instructor.  All of what his classes have this common emphasis: Understand the fundamentals conceptually, and what follows (meaning the details of the subject at hand) will fall into place in a meaningful way. I Love this approach for learning personally.  Its rare to find an instructor that has the knowledge, conveys that knowledge beautifully, and tends to anticipate perfectly what questions a rational mind might have at just the right time.  This class, because of the instructor, I believe is one where the knowledge gained is truly integrated into one's own existing knowledge, as opposed to more of a rote memory of 'arbitrary magic' approach; and when that happens, what is learned sticks around a lot longer and is picked up quicker.

results.content:
Whether you're coming to Angular with a bit of experience with it already under your belt or without any experience at all, I would wholeheartedly recommend this course.

I first dove into Angular a few months ago with a relatively brief tutorial on another website. The  tutorial was OK, a bit short, not a lot of explanation of what goes on behind the scenes. I eventually built some of my own small Angular applications and got a pretty good feel for things with a lot of trial and error, but I still had a lot of questions about why things were a certain way, and how pieces of Angular worked.

This course, on the other hand, is really quite in-depth. In my short few months using Angular previous to going through this course, I've built up a lot of questions about how certain aspects work (what is dependency injection? how does Angular really handle page views? what exactly are services?), and so far this course has answered all my questions.

I should also mention that the presentation of this course, visually, is quite nice too. Tony is awesome :D
results.content_html:

results.content: I've taken another AngularJS course that was more hands on in their approach with Angular and you got to start making apps right away while learning a little bit about it, but never truly understanding how it works. This course does a great job explaining how AngularJS works and what its doing.

results.content:
I had previously worked through some tutorials, including the phone-cat tutorials, and I was really confused and slightly overwhelmed by how complicated everything seemed.  I have a fair amount of building back-end non-java script applications using frameworks such as Rails, Django, and Spring MVC and thought I would just pick things right up with Angular even though I have minimal javascript background, but I found these concepts much more difficult than back-end development because they are structured in a very unfamiliar way in comparison.

After taking this course over a two day weekend I truly do UNDERSTAND the concepts of every single code sample provided and what I have written. All the concepts I was previously confused about in the past are now much better understood and I am excited about building some front-end applications with my own back-end API's. 

I was truly blown away by the quality of these lectures - thank you very much!

results.content:
The course is excellent for developers of all that want to learn about  front-end web development using AngularJS  because it covers all the requirements to start building single page web applications using the MV* architecture.

The lectures are very good because they introduce gradually the foundations of AngularJS, allowing a solid understanding of the framework, teaching  the concepts  behind scene and at the same time the examples that make it easy to follow with grace and perfect balance.

With the foundations given by this course  is possible to start developing single web page applications in a confident, organized, and well-architectured, robust  manner. 

In short, after this course you will have all the concepts and confidence required to start building webPages using AngularJS.
results.content_html:
The course is excellent for developers of all that want to learn about front-end web development using AngularJS because it covers all the requirements to start building single page web applications using the MV* architecture.

The lectures are very good because they introduce gradually the foundations of AngularJS, allowing a solid understanding of the framework, teaching the concepts behind scene and at the same time the examples that make it easy to follow with grace and perfect balance.

With the foundations given by this course is possible to start developing single web page applications in a confident, organized, and well-architectured, robust manner.

In short, after this course you will have all the concepts and confidence required to start building webPages using AngularJS.

results.content: This is another tremendous course from Tony. His approach of explaining not just the how, but also the why of the material is what truly makes it stick for me. I had no experience with Angular previous to this and am confident I can build some pretty powerful apps with it. Tony is thorough and methodical as he carefully arranges the material in a way that's easy to understand. This is my second of Tony's courses. The first one I took was Javascript Understanding the Weird Parts, which I also strongly recommend. If you're looking for a good course that presents challenging material in a very digestible manner, look no further.

results.content: I recently started my first career job with an insurance company.  I've just graduated from a university with a degree in Computer Science, emphasizing in computer technologies.  Our company is making a big push to use AngularJS for our projects so it was necessary that I learn it.  Through all of the JavaScript courses, the Angular courses and the JQuery courses I took to prepare, this one really stood out.  Examples are clear and easy to follow and the exercises build on each other very well.  Doing the weather SPA was great, especially if you actually try to do it yourself before watching ahead in the videos.  The only complaint I have is that there isn't more content!  If there is an advanced AngularJS course, I'd be interested in doing something like that.
results.content_html: I recently started my first career job with an insurance company. I've just graduated from a university with a degree in Computer Science, emphasizing in computer technologies. Our company is making a big push to use AngularJS for our projects so it was necessary that I learn it. Through all of the JavaScript courses, the Angular courses and the JQuery courses I took to prepare, this one really stood out. Examples are clear and easy to follow and the exercises build on each other very well. Doing the weather SPA was great, especially if you actually try to do it yourself before watching ahead in the videos. The only complaint I have is that there isn't more content! If there is an advanced AngularJS course, I'd be interested in doing something like that.

results.content:
Excellent. I got handed an AngularJS application at the end of 2019 (!) to maintain having worked with Angular6+ for the preceeding year. This course helped me to not only understand many of the "wierd" things in the AngularJS app that I had no understanding of ($scope: {something: "="} for example, couldn't figure out how to search that on the net), but this course also gave me a better undestanding of Angular 2.0 by explaining much of the basis and history of 1.x that I was able to apply to my knowledge of 2.x. So this course still has a lot of value for web-des as we go into 2020. 
Anthony speaks very clearly, describes what he is doing well and is precise, given the topic at hand. 
It's really helped me do my job on what is now a legacy framework, where finding help on forums is becoming more difficult as devs move on and lose interest in Angular 1.x.
I will definately find myself revisiting some of these lectures as time goes on, cementing my knowledge of a framework that required support in the workplace.

results.content:
Excellent overall introduction to AngularJS (and HTML, JavaScript, web development).  Breadth and depth of coverage is good.  Good instructor, good tips.

Course materials (video and files) appear mostly created in 2014.
For the Daily Temperature Single Page Application (lessons 45, 46, 47), there are updates needed to get code running as expected web app in Google Chrome browser in 2018.  Suggest do a quick review of student questions and answers to see the difficult parts, summarize, and add summarized addendum/tips/updates to the lessons 45,46,47 in particular.

results.content: Its been long time (years) I was trying to start AngularJS.. but for the big words (though I am from CS Background) and unclear tutorials available in web, I was always afraid of it and I couldn't start. I'll just propose you to add a bonus lecture on Performance Tuning of AngularJS, as while working on real world application, I found there are drawbacks of 2way Data binding and need to take measures to keep the site memory low and handle watchers, dirty checking etc. If you can put some light on these issues, it would be great.

results.content:
I love how the teacher actually explains *why* things are the way they are, rather than just giving you code to copy. I've tried learning Angular before and gave up because it was seemingly impossible, I'd just get error after error when running my apps.

This course in the first few lectures has literally filled the gaps and pieced together all of the issues I was seeing, so far, I completely understand what I did wrong last time.

Note to teacher: I absolutely love the 'Asides', even if just to remind me of something in Javascript/HTML that I may have forgotten before using it in your course has made it so much easier to properly understand what I am trying to do.

I'm genuinely exited to re-write some of my normal ASP/Javascript/JQuery apps in Angular!

Kudos.

results.content:
I rarely write reviews when it comes to courses because they either ultimately disappoint me, or I don't feel compelled to share my thoughts on the lectures etc.

Learn and Understand AngularJS however, deserves all the high reviews it has received. The course itself is very well laid out in terms of topics to cover, and you can clearly notice that the lecturer has put considerable time into planning the actual course from start to finish.

As for Anthony (the lecturer) — he is without doubt the best teacher I have encountered on Udemy. His teaching style is excellent; clear and concise. He makes even the complete newbie to AngularJS eager to learn, learn and learn!

By the end of the course you feel a sense of accomplishment in that you build a SPA, utilising the most powerful of concepts in Angular and web development in general. 

Following the completion of the course, it gives you what you need to start building well-structured, modern, and in-demand web applications. Thanks to the lecturer for his good work, and I look forward to the upcoming JavaScript course that is due to be released!

As for Anthony (the lecturer) — he is without doubt the best teacher I have encountered on Udemy. His teaching style is excellent; clear and concise. He makes even the complete newbie to AngularJS eager to learn, learn and learn!

By the end of the course you feel a sense of accomplishment in that you build a SPA, utilising the most powerful of concepts in Angular and web development in general.

Following the completion of the course, it gives you what you need to start building well-structured, modern, and in-demand web applications. Thanks to the lecturer for his good work, and I look forward to the upcoming JavaScript course that is due to be released!

results.content: This course is excellent if you approach it correctly. In the first lesson Anthony says don't imitate, but seek to understand. I tried imitating the first time through, furiously typing along and trying to make things work. Had I heeded Anthony's advice, I wouldn't be going through a second time. Grab a good notebook and take notes, and try to understand the concepts rather than try to get the source code to work, and this course will make everything clear. I used to hate Angular, and now I actually enjoy working with it, because I understand what's going on.

results.content: I took this course in 2017, Angular 4 is here now. Take this course if you very new to Angular world ... otherwise if you want to you may jump to Angular 4 bandwagon straight.

results.content: The concepts were well explained and the teacher gives a thorough description of AngularJS. However, the course would have greatly benefitted from short exercises interspersed within the lectures. Instead of waiting to build that app at the end of the course, let's have more short challenges at the end of each chapter which force us to practice what we've learned. Then when we bring it together at the end, we'll be sure it really sticks.

results.content:
Excellent information. Course content is structured to understand help understand key Angular concepts.  Videos were engaging and kept my interest throughout.  Normally I have to rewind videos to understand parts that I missed.

One thing I would have liked to see was perhaps a list of key Angular directives that are useful from Anthony's experience.  For example, the ng-submit was mentioned in the bonus lecture (and I hope that additional information will be added based on student feedback).  Similarly, having pointers to key directives would be useful. 

 Also, information on design patterns for creating an enterprise level application with Angular JS would be very useful.  That might be out of scope for this course but a separate course that covers design challenges and solutions with Angular JS would be great.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Overall, I felt this was an excellent course. It is well taught with simplified, but accurate and thorough, explanations of the various concepts taught throughout the course.

The instruction either practiced his delivery extensively or re-recorded his videos until they were perfect as there is no stammering, minimal ums and ahs, and virtually no mistakes in delivery or coding (except when done intentionally as a teaching tool).

The only drawback to the course is that openweathermap.org changed their APIs at some point after the course was created and recorded. Although the instructor did address the changes to the API call in an inserted lesson, the rest of the lessons still used the old API call method, which created confusion for many students, including myself. 

In addition, the daily weather forecast API used by the instructor for the single page application lessons is no longer free. If the student attempts to use the same API as the instructor, s/he will receive errors back without any explanation. This was frustrating. I finally found the answer I needed to continue in the Q&A section, but it shouldn't have been the responsibility of students to figure this out and inform the rest of the students. In addition, students should not have to pay for tools and data to complete courses unless they desire to do so. I wish the instructor would redo the SPA lessons using one of the free APIs.

Those two changes would make the course more relevant and less confusing, despite the fact that there are newer versions of AngularJS available.

Despite the obvious aging of the course as described above, I do recommend this course to anyone interested in learning the basics of  AngularJS.

results.content:
UPDATED REVIEW:
I bought this (and the NodeJS course) when they were each less than $50. At the sub-$50, range, they were a great deal. The tipping point, though, is around $65. I just can't recommend this course at $175. It's good, but it's not THAT good. You'd do better buying 3 or 4 other courses with your $175 than spending all your money on this one.

ORIGINAL POST (5 stars)
I purchased this course after going through Tony's "Learn and Understand Node.js". I'm a longtime C#/.NET developer, just now starting into Node.js, and this is helping me immensely understand the whole system from top to bottom. 

One of my favorite things about Tony is the pace at which he speaks. At first, I would listen to each one of the videos at 1x speed, but then I found that I can really still focus on things and get it done in half the time by speeding things up to 2x. The good thing about the pace of his speech is that it's still VERY understandable at 2x, but I still have the option of slowing it down to 1x whenever he is going through actual code with which I want to follow along. 

I can't emphasize enough how well put together this course is. If you're trying to learn Angular.js, and you want something that is also a mild refresher in Javascript, but doesn't insult your experience or intelligence, I wouldn't hesitate to buy this one.

I can't emphasize enough how well put together this course is. If you're trying to learn Angular.js, and you want something that is also a mild refresher in Javascript, but doesn't insult your experience or intelligence, I wouldn't hesitate to buy this one.

results.content:
I've programmed with the AngularJS quite a bit in the past, but often felt like I was letting the magic happen - not really what understanding what was going on.

This course really helped me to understand how and why AngularJS works the way it does and went a long way towards demystifying what is often thought to be a confusing framework.

The course doesn't take you incredibly deep, but I think it gives you the tools to go deep yourself without getting lost.

Looking forward to more courses from this instructor.

results.content:
Kinda like playing the original "Starcraft: Brood War" felt a few years ago, this course feels like it was a great course when it was released, but desperately needs an update.

And just like with Starcraft, there are 2 possible ways it could be updated:

- Create a new version of the course for the new version of Angular.
- Update the course for the latest version of Angular (1.6.9), perhaps featuring a bit of modern tooling where applicable.

I decided to take this course knowing that AngularJS was out-of-date, but as a freelance developer, I can say that it seems to be the most popular "legacy" front-end framework outside the more modern options of Vue, Angular 2+, and React.

You have to follow the Q&A and perhaps do a rare bit of Googling every once in a while if you decide to use the latest version of Angular with the lessons (which you probably should do, since it seems pointless to specifically learn the arbitrary 1.3.0rc1-rc2 versions when much newer stable versions are available).

Tony is a great instructor who always seems to have well-planned courses, and that in-depth, methodical nature is probably a major factor stopping him from updating this course (or slowing him down, at least).

results.content:
I know Angular 2/4 is all the rage right now. Yet enterprise world is lagging as usual a few years behind and our frameworks still use AngularJS 1.x so I was looking for material to refresh some of the prior knowledge I had on the subject.

I believe this is hands down the best AngularJS 1.x material I've seen.

Excellent and really clean and to the point explanations. Many concepts and the ideas behind them explained in a logical and easy to understand way. 

Gives me an overall vision of what Angular Team was aiming for, and the purpose for modules, scope, controllers, services and directives and how they fit together.

I hope Tony will build more courses as I will definitely buy all of them! Great content, great quality, a very knowledgeable instructor with a gift for teaching.

If you are looking for Angular 1.x training, do yourself a favor and try Tony's course. 

If you want to go in more advanced depth I can also recommend the "Build your own AngularJS" book (https://teropa.info/build-your-own-angular/) to clearly understand the magic behind the curtain, yet that should only come after you understand the purpose and how everything fits together which Tony explains so well.

Amazing work and effort by Tony! I hope he will keep delivering more value with his great approach on newer courses :)

Thank you!

results.content:
I have 27 years of solid hands on, every day coding experience in plethora of stable languages. I had been trying to understand the under the hood version of AngularJS framework from last 4 weeks. Have read almost all postings on the internet, but was not feeling confident----something was missing, and then while surfing google links, I saw this course, and listened to Tony's promise of not just running you at the speed of light with quick clips, but instead will actually pass on rudimentary but foundational knowledge of ng. Well! let me tell you---the course is an impeccable demonstration of knowledge, passion,  and love for teaching. The material is presented very clearly and flows well. The confusing topics of AngularJS framework were slowly but surely injected in my brain when taking this course. I was literally attached with my machine for the entire weekend, plus most of yesterday---and now feel sorry to see the conclusion of this course. This was, if nothing, but an engrossing series of lectures, leaving behind a solid and sound knowledge of AngularJS.

I would love to attend a course on a confusing topics like '$q promises', restangular, and ui.router. All three of these frameworks are deep and confusing--perfect topics to be taught by Tony.

Tony, my good friend----u r the best and least I can say is that you have done justice to the cause. I love your passion for teaching---please keep up the good work and I wish the best with your newly married life and you have the very best of 2015 and very many new years ahead of your young and promising life.

results.content:
I found this course to be EXTREMELY beneficial in understanding the core concepts of AngularJS , in regards to being able to read the code and understand the flow pattern of AngularJS. 

I thought that the course could have used more "Stop and Do it yourself points".    Yes, the viewer could have stopped on their own at any point, however, I think most people would probably just watch straight through until they are told to "Stop and Do it yourself" , which doesn't happen until Section 8, and by that point several of the concepts that the person has to do were so far back , that it's a good chance of not remembering what needs to be done, or exactly what video to go looking for. 

Other than that, I really enjoyed the course.

results.content:
Very well laid out, logical and thorough.  The subject is the JavaScript Framework, so you must know basic javascript programming.  Complex javascript concepts used by Angular1 are explained well in the course.

Encapsulated lessons divided into logical chunks with a great progression from lesson to lesson.  This course focuses purely on Angular1 with some bootstrap CSS for real world styling.  

You'll need to know how basic bootstrap styling works if you want things pretty, so read up about the bootstrap grid system and the navbar component of bootstrap if you aren't already familiar.

You'll need to know how basic bootstrap styling works if you want things pretty, so read up about the bootstrap grid system and the navbar component of bootstrap if you aren't already familiar.

Anthony is a rare teacher; in that he is excited about what he teaches, is engaging, and is very articulate. He ignites the fires within his students by truly imparting his knowledge, wisdom, and enthusiasm about [AngularJS].
I am not a book learner, I learn by doing and trying to understand why it needs to be done. Anthony makes sure to keep his informational slides to the just whats required - meaning more doing.
Previous to taking this class I have built Angular-based Flask/Python applications; however I now have an understanding of the concepts and foundations that I took for granted before and suddenly it all makes more sense!
If I have anything to critique it would be
1. I wanted more at the end; like a good dessert
2. Provide an option to download All the resource files at once; it broke up the flow when I had to pause the course while I setup for the next section.
Suggestions -
1. Adding the Weather Description and its corresponding Icon - better user experience;
2. instead of just adding the Submit functionality, use the bootstrap input-group to make it more application-like interface - better user experience;
3. being able to incorporate a pre-generated list (local JSON or CSV file) of cities with type-ahead in the text box - working with external sources;
4. add a radio selector to the main view which selects how to view temperature deg-Celsius|deg-Fahrenheit - working with multiple input parameters;
5. show how to generate/use child controllers by adding ability to view 3 favorite cities at once - Working with external sources (create, read, update, delete) and child controllers;
6. using constants - setting external URL's as a constant and referring to it;
7. concatenating all app components - instead of "var myApp = angular.module(...)..." and referencing myApp.service etc. ... just use 'angular.module('myApp', []) ... .service .controller etc.' - explain when and why you would want to do that.

results.content: Great course overall but I have several comments (suggestions). I think that quizes and/or programming assignments would help retain learnt knowledge. I wish the course would go more in depth but it certainly is not shallow (it is introductory course anyway). Sometimes, Tony repeat himself but nothing to really complain about. I was a little bit surprised that Tony never showed his face in this course but maybe he has a reason for that. I wished that discussed code snippets were highlighted and that we could see views (HTML documents), template(s) and JavaScript code (directive definitions etc) were visible at the same time instead of bouncing back and forth between 2-3 files (that was really apparent in custom directive sections). This would really would help to see connection between different pieces. IDE (Brackets here) is not the greatest presentation tool, I think that few Powerpoint presentation would really help here. These are my suggestions. This course is worth every penny for sure and Tony is efficient teaching this course (not much time wasters here). Thank you, Tony. Great job.

results.content:
Tony explains complex topics in a simple way, I believe it's a great way to start learning AngularJS before diving into more technical tools (forums, books, APIs, code snippets, & more).
Topics covered:
 - Javascript: covering some core Javascript programming concepts when necessary, this ensures everyone can understand following explanations on AngularJS
 - MV*: explanation & demystification
 - Dependency Injection in AngularJS
 - The scope service 
 - 2 ways data binding in AngularJS
 - Watchers, Routing, Controllers, Reusable Components
 - Build a small Single Page App using all the knowledge covered
results.content_html:
Tony explains complex topics in a simple way, I believe it's a great way to start learning AngularJS before diving into more technical tools (forums, books, APIs, code snippets, & more).
Topics covered:
- Javascript: covering some core Javascript programming concepts when necessary, this ensures everyone can understand following explanations on AngularJS
- MV*: explanation & demystification
- Dependency Injection in AngularJS
- The scope service
- 2 ways data binding in AngularJS
- Watchers, Routing, Controllers, Reusable Components
- Build a small Single Page App using all the knowledge covered

results.content: This course is one of the best I've ever taken in anything, ever.  It teaches what lies behind the code so you understand what you are doing and why, rather than just being told "this is how you do it".  You can always look up syntax, but having an understanding of the whys enables you to think through problems.  Acquiring that knowledge is far more difficult than learning the syntax of "hello, world".   Anthony Alicea is a gifted teacher.  I wish more, actually, all, courses were taught this way.  I would take any course he taught.  My only "complaint" is that I would like to have screen shots/copies of the code presented in the videos.  I found that the Start/Finish code offered as a download wasn't always complete (the Finished version in particular), and there were times I would have liked to have been able to study something in a manner more convenient than pausing/rewinding the video.  But that is a minor point.  All in all, this is a model of what good course structure content and excellent teaching is all about.  I can't  say enough good things about course or teacher.  Thank you for making this available.
results.content_html: This course is one of the best I've ever taken in anything, ever. It teaches what lies behind the code so you understand what you are doing and why, rather than just being told "this is how you do it". You can always look up syntax, but having an understanding of the whys enables you to think through problems. Acquiring that knowledge is far more difficult than learning the syntax of "hello, world". Anthony Alicea is a gifted teacher. I wish more, actually, all, courses were taught this way. I would take any course he taught. My only "complaint" is that I would like to have screen shots/copies of the code presented in the videos. I found that the Start/Finish code offered as a download wasn't always complete (the Finished version in particular), and there were times I would have liked to have been able to study something in a manner more convenient than pausing/rewinding the video. But that is a minor point. All in all, this is a model of what good course structure content and excellent teaching is all about. I can't say enough good things about course or teacher. Thank you for making this available.

results.content:
Tony, in his usual fashion, thoroughly explains enough of what is going on "under" the hood to quickly bring you up to speed. 

Many other authors quickly dive into a working "Hello, World" example without explaining much, leaving the student to wonder what is going on. Tony takes a different approach; he starts off describing Angular, why you should use it, and where to get it. Each step is explained in detail as he goes, meaning by not jumping right in, you learn what is happening and why.

This was a great course from top to bottom. I took this course because the AngularJS documentation is absolutely awful and felt I would benefit from a one-on-one style video lecture.

Anthony is a gifted instructor who was able to break down highly technical concepts so I could wrap my head around Angular. The pace is just right and he really challenges you in all the right areas.

You will only need to know HTML, CSS, and the basics of JavaScript in order to follow along with this course. "Learn and Understand AngularJS" has been an invaluable experience that I will consistently refer to in the future as I continue with AngularJS.

results.content:
This course provided a good intro to the framework. It explained a lot of things that aren't covered in the books I was trying to read (like the existence of the digest).

Basically, I was having difficulty getting through a book and was able to watch this course, do the demos, and then breeze through the book and some other online literature and get pretty fluent with Angular.

It would have been nice if the course had some more in depth examples of directives and explained the difference between controllers and link functions as well as the order those functions are processed. Some better coverage of services would be good as well.

Overall though, the instructor does a good job with organizing the material into succinct classes that aren't too long and upon completing the course, the student should be able to understand the framework enough to start a project in Angular.

A very good course.
results.content_html:

results.content: You can get pretty far in AngularJS without really understanding what you're doing. At least, that was the case for me. I was a month into learning AngularJS and created an app that accomplished a lot of what I was hoping to do.  I began to worry, however, that perhaps my application was not using 'best practices' and perhaps could be a lot more efficient.  I was mainly interested in learning about services and factories and I was not disappointed.  This course isn't just for the very new to AngularJS.  I think it was perfect for those with some basic experience as well.  Excellent course.

I wish more courses followed Tony's approach, and I already am underway in his Javascript: Understanding the Weird Parts course which is equally awesome (and a VERY good follow-up to this course). I'm confident that when I get to his node.js course I won't be disappointed!

results.content:
I took this course as a professional software developer with plenty of web development experience but no experience using AngularJS. I was hoping that this would give me a firm foundation upon which to build going forward, and that is definitely what I got.

Of course, it's hard to know how much of the AngularJS iceberg is still hidden from view and how much was revealed by taking this course. Regardless, I think any more would have been overwhelming, and unnecessary, to me at this point. I'm quote confident now that can cross those bridges as and when I need to.

The course was well paced, simple to follow without being condescending and offered detailed background that helped me understand why it is the way it is as opposed to just knowing a rote answer to a particular problem. The last point is very important to me as it means I'm not limited to being able to solve a small set of problems but I can apply my understanding to solve problems beyond the scope of this course.

results.content:
The instructor does an excellent job of first introducing you to the origins and underlying theory of each concept before gradually scaling up with functionality, implementation and practical examples. Each lecture has associated resources:(1)starter files with skeleton code that begin where the lecture begins, and (2) one set of completed files that contains the final result of the lecture. This is helpful because you have the option of working along with the instructor or watching the video first, then attempting to achieve the same results using the completed files as a reference. The latter was my preferred method, because it gave me time to focus on the lecture then see how much I was able to retain and apply, making it easier to identify the gaps in my understanding. Other sites/instructors/resources for learning AngularJS tend to provide too many hints/pre-filled code resulting in false confidence and leaving you even more confused in the end. 

The instructor also does a very good job of NOT glossing over crucial details about underlying functionality. Understanding the motivations and inner-workings of Angular's features affords ease of use and enables you to make sound design decisions.

I was able to work through the entire course in a weekend, and successfully land a job as an Angular developer the following day. One of the most important things that the instructor teaches you is how to continue to expand your knowledge of the language and how to prepare for future developments.

One course addition that I would find helpful, would be to have 5-10 practice applications (with fully outlined specifications/constraints - as if provided by a client), to further apply and challenge my knowledge of the language and concepts taught in the course.

Overall the instructor was very knowledgeable and delivered the content in a manner that was easily digestible. I would recommend this course to those new to web development, and even seasoned developers looking to fill in the gaps and expand their skill sets.

Thanks Anthony!

results.content:
I picked up this course as my new job had a legacy application on AngularJS.

This course is great for beginners, as various "big words" are explained simply.

If you're more experienced, you'll be able to skim through it quite quickly and get up and running on AngularJS.

This is a really good course for anyone wanting foundations. It's slightly out-dated (no components, for example), but the missing parts can be complimented on YouTube. The author also skips through certain things (like provider and factories) but openly says so, and same thing, can easily be complemented with a YouTube.

Overall very happy with this course.

results.content:
I started this course with no knowledge of AngularJS, and I was searching aimlessly on YouTube and Google and downloaded a few online e-books to try to learn AngularJS on my own.  However, the process was painful.  Even though I had some software development experiences, the e-books and the random videos did not help much as I had so many questions, and I wanted to understand the reasons behind all the syntax, not just to copy and modify some codes.  

Luckily, one day I found the first hour preview of this video on YouTube.  I followed through and just within that hour, so many of my questions were answered, and I got a page up and running.  I was so thrilled and wanted to learn more and I finally got here and registered for the course immediately.

The instructor speaks very clearly, builds up the course progressively, explains why and how, and in the end he connects everything he had taught altogether.  The pace of the course is just right, and the section separations are very helpful as it was very easy for me to search back to a specific topic when I needed it.  The quality of the video is very nice, there is a HD version, but the font and the screen worked fine with me without HD.  

I highly recommend this course for anyone who is a beginner in AngularJS and wants to understand this framework well.  I really enjoy Anthony's course, and would definitely take other courses with him in the future.

results.content: This course delivered the information in an obviously very carefully thought out way building up your knowledge as it dives into each topic. With extra asides to explain how the HTML and JavaScript are both working in the background. The instructor is clear and engaging. My only criticism was that it was fairly slow to get into the good stuff but I've been a developer for a long time and am just new to Angular so I think the back to basics approach is needed for people starting Angular without a development background. Honestly a brilliant course. Can't praise it enough!

results.content: This is a great course. Starts off gently and eases into Angular post some robust introduction about model, view and how to architect a web application. From this course, I could gather that starting off with Angular is really easy. Writing your first Angular application is also easy. Where this course and the author excels is how deep he goes into explaining nitty gritties like dependency injection, dirty checking, building your own directive etc. Section-7 on Custom Directives is pretty robust, one of the best there available on the internet. A one star less because some parts like compiling and linking a directive are hurriedly explained. Hands down the best introductory course to Angular.
